briefdescription.para: A type representing an axis-aligned cuboid.

detaileddescription.para: It must be a model of Traits::Iso_cuboid_3. Used to represent the original domain.

briefdescription.para: Integer triple to store the number of sheets in each direction of space.
The point type of the triangulation.

simplesect.para: This type is equal to Geom_traits::Point_3 when considering periodic Delaunay triangulations and to Geom_traits::Weighted_point_3 when considering periodic weighted Delaunay triangulations.

briefdescription.para: The geometric basic 3D point type.

memberdef.definition: typedef std::pair< Point, Offset > CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_point
memberdef.name: Periodic_point

briefdescription.para: Represents a point-offset pair.

detaileddescription.para: The point in the pair lies in the original domain. Note that the inner type is Point.

memberdef.definition: typedef std::pair< Point_3, Offset > CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_point_3
memberdef.name: Periodic_point_3

briefdescription.para: Represents a point-offset pair.

detaileddescription.para: The point in the pair lies in the original domain. Note that the inner type is Point_3.

memberdef.definition: typedef array< Periodic_point, 2> CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_segment
memberdef.name: Periodic_segment

briefdescription.para: A periodic segment.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the inner type is Periodic_point.

memberdef.definition: typedef array< Periodic_point_3, 2> CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_segment_3
memberdef.name: Periodic_segment_3

briefdescription.para: A periodic segment.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the inner type is Periodic_point_3.

memberdef.definition: typedef array< Periodic_point, 3> CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_triangle
memberdef.name: Periodic_triangle

briefdescription.para: A periodic triangle.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the inner type is Periodic_point.

memberdef.definition: typedef array< Periodic_point_3, 3> CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_triangle_3
memberdef.name: Periodic_triangle_3

briefdescription.para: A periodic triangle.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the inner type is Periodic_point_3.

memberdef.definition: typedef array< Periodic_point, 4> CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_tetrahedron
memberdef.name: Periodic_tetrahedron

briefdescription.para: A periodic tetrahedron.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the inner type is Periodic_point.

memberdef.definition: typedef array< Periodic_point_3, 4> CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS >::Periodic_tetrahedron_3
memberdef.name: Periodic_tetrahedron_3

briefdescription.para: A periodic tetrahedron.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the inner type is Periodic_point_3.

description.para: Only vertices ( $ 0$-faces) and cells ( $ 3$-faces) are stored.
Edges ( $ 1$-faces) and facets ( $ 2$-faces) are not explicitly represented and thus there are no corresponding classes (see Section Representation).
The vertices and faces of the triangulations are accessed through handles, iterators and circulators.

A handle is a type which supports the two dereference operators and operator->. The Handle concept is documented in the support library. Iterators and circulators are bidirectional and non-mutable. The edges and facets of the triangulation can also be visited through iterators and circulators which are bidirectional and non-mutable.
Iterators and circulators are convertible to the corresponding handles, thus the user can pass them directly as arguments to the functions.

briefdescription.para: handle to a vertex
handle to a cell
Size type (an unsigned integral type)
Difference type (a signed integral type)
iterator over cells
iterator over facets
iterator over edges
iterator over vertices
iterator over the vertices whose corresponding points lie in the original domain, i.e. for each set of periodic copies the Unique_vertex_iterator iterates over exactly one representative.
circulator over all cells incident to a given edge
circulator over all facets incident to a given edge

description.para: The following iterators have value type Periodic_segment, Periodic_triangle, and Periodic_tetrahedron, which have inner type Point.

briefdescription.para: iterator over the tetrahedra corresponding to cells of the triangulation.
iterator over the triangles corresponding to facets of the triangulation.
iterator over the segments corresponding to edges of the triangulation.
iterator over the points corresponding to vertices of the triangulation.
The enum Locate_type is defined by Periodic_3_triangulation_3 to specify which case occurs when locating a point in the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: If the triangulation does not contain any points EMPTY is returned.

briefdescription.para: Return all geometric primitives as they are stored internally in Triangulation_data_structure_3.
Return only one representative of each geometric primitive even if the triangulation is computed in a multiply sheeted covering space.

detaileddescription.para: Choose the representative whose maximum offset is minimal but non-negative in each direction of space.

briefdescription.para: Same as STORED but return additionally all primitives whose intersection with the original domain of the current covering space is non-empty.
Same as UNIQUE but return additionally all primitives whose intersection with the original domain is non-empty.
The enum Iterator_type is defined by Periodic_3_triangulation_3 to specify the behavior of geometric iterators.

detaileddescription.para: The elements of the enum have the following meaning:

briefdescription.para: Introduces an empty triangulation t with domain as original domain.
Copy constructor.

detaileddescription.para: All vertices and faces are duplicated.

briefdescription.para: The triangulation tr is duplicated, and modifying the copy after the duplication does not modify the original.

detaileddescription.para: The previous triangulation held by t is deleted.

briefdescription.para: The triangulations tr and t are swapped.

detaileddescription.para: t.swap(tr) should be preferred to t = tr or to t(tr) if tr is deleted after that. Indeed, there is no copy of cells and vertices, thus this method runs in constant time.

briefdescription.para: Deletes all vertices and all cells of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS1 > &t1, const Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS2 > &t2)
memberdef.name: operator==

briefdescription.para: Equality operator.

detaileddescription.para: Returns true iff there exist a bijection between the vertices of t1 and those of t2 and a bijection between the cells of t1 and those of t2, which preserve the geometry of the triangulation, that is, the points of each corresponding pair of vertices are equal, and the tetrahedra corresponding to each pair of cells are equal (up to a permutation of their vertices).

memberdef.argsstring: (const Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS1 > &t1, const Periodic_3_triangulation_3< Traits, TDS2 > &t2)
memberdef.name: operator!=

briefdescription.para: The opposite of operator==.
Returns a const reference to the geometric traits object.
Returns a const reference to the triangulation data structure.
Returns the original domain.
This is an advanced function.

detaileddescription.para: Returns the number of sheets of the covering space the triangulation is currently computed in.

briefdescription.para: Get the offset between the origins of the internal offset coordinate systems of two neighboring cells with respect from ch to its i-th neighbor.
This is an advanced function.

detaileddescription.para: Changes the domain. Note that this function calls clear(), i.e., it erases the existing triangulation.

briefdescription.para: This is an advanced function.

detaileddescription.para: Returns a reference to the triangulation data structure.

The responsibility of keeping a valid triangulation belongs to the user when using advanced operations allowing a direct manipulation of the tds. This method is mainly a help for users implementing their own triangulation algorithms.

briefdescription.para: The current triangulation remains a triangulation in the 1-sheeted covering space even after adding points if this method returns true.

detaileddescription.para: This test relies on a heuristic, i.e. if it answers false nothing is known. This test runs in constant-time when not computing in the 1-sheeted covering space. (This test uses the length of the longest edge in the triangulation as a criterion [1].)

briefdescription.para: The same as is_extensible_triangulation_in_1_sheet_h1() but with a more precise heuristic, i.e. it might answer true in cases in which is_extensible_triangulation_in_1_sheet_h1() would not.

detaileddescription.para: However, it is much less time efficient when not computing in the 1-sheeted covering space. (This test uses the diameter of the largest empty ball in the input point set as a criterion [1].)

briefdescription.para: Returns true if the current triangulation would still be a triangulation in the 1-sheeted covering space, returns false otherwise.
Converts the current triangulation into the same periodic triangulation in the 1-sheeted covering space.

simplesect.para: It is not recommended to interfere with the built-in covering management. Especially a premature conversion to the 1-sheeted covering space might lead to problems when modifying the triangulation later.

briefdescription.para: Converts the current triangulation into the same periodic triangulation in the 27-sheeted covering space.

simplesect.para: It is not recommended to interfere with the built-in covering management. Especially a premature conversion to the 1-sheeted covering space might lead to problems when modifying the triangulation later.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of vertices.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all vertices that are representatives of the same point in $ \mathbb T_c^3$ as one vertex.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of cells.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all cells that are representatives of the same tetrahedron in $ \mathbb T_c^3$ as one cell.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of vertices in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_vertices().

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of cells in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_cells().

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of edges.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all edges that are representatives of the same segment in $ \mathbb T_c^3$ as one edge.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of facets.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all facets that are representatives of the same triangle in $ \mathbb T_c^3$ as one facet.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of edges in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_edges().

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of facets in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_facets().

description.para: The following functions return object of types Periodic_segment, Periodic_triangle, and Periodic_tetrahedron, which have inner type Point.

briefdescription.para: Returns the periodic point given by vertex v.

detaileddescription.para: If t is represented in the 1-sheeted covering space, the offset is always zero. Otherwise v can correspond to a periodic copy outside domain of an input point.

briefdescription.para: If t is represented in the 1-sheeted covering space, this function returns the periodic point given by the $ i$-th vertex of cell c, that is the point in the original domain and the offset of the vertex in c.

detaileddescription.para:
If t is represented in the 27-sheeted covering space, this offset is possibly added to another offset determining the periodic copy.
$ i \in\{0,1,2,3\}$

memberdef.argsstring: (const Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: periodic_segment

briefdescription.para: Returns the periodic segment formed by the two point-offset pairs corresponding to the two vertices of edge (c,i,j).

memberdef.argsstring: (const Cell_handle c, Offset offset, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: periodic_segment

briefdescription.para: Returns the periodic segment formed by the two point-offset pairs corresponding to the two vertices of edge (c,i,j).

detaileddescription.para:
A translation in accordance with offset is applied on the point-offet pairs.
$ i,j \in\{0,1,2,3\}$, $ i\neq j$

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for edge e.
Returns the periodic triangle formed by the three point-offset pairs corresponding to the three vertices of facet (c,i).

detaileddescription.para:
The triangle is oriented so that its normal points to the inside of cell c.
$ i \in\{0,1,2,3\}$

memberdef.argsstring: (const Cell_handle c, Offset offset, int i) const
memberdef.name: periodic_triangle

briefdescription.para: Returns the periodic triangle formed by the three point-offset pairs corresponding to the three vertices of facet (c,i).

detaileddescription.para: A translation in accordance with offset is applied on the point-offet pairs.

The triangle is oriented so that its normal points to the inside of cell c.
$ i \in\{0,1,2,3\}$

briefdescription.para: Same as the previous method for facet f.
Returns the periodic tetrahedron formed by the four point-offset pairs corresponding to the four vertices of c.
Returns the periodic tetrahedron formed by the four point-offset pairs corresponding to the four vertices of c.

detaileddescription.para: A translation in accordance with offset is applied on the point-offet pairs.

description.para: The following functions were renamed with CGAL 4.11 to clarify that they return geometric objects with inner type Point_3. Note that a traits class providing exact constructions should be used in order to guarantee the following operations to be exact (as opposed to computing the triangulation only, which requires only exact predicates).

briefdescription.para: Converts the periodic point of type PP to a Point_3.

detaileddescription.para: The type PP can be either Periodic_point or Periodic_point_3.

briefdescription.para: Converts the Point p to a Point_3.
Same as above, with offsets.
Converts the periodic segment of type PS to a Segment.

detaileddescription.para: The type PS can be either Periodic_segment or Periodic_segment_3.

briefdescription.para: Creates a segment from two points.

detaileddescription.para: The type P can be either Point or Point_3.

memberdef.argsstring: (const P &p1, const P &p2, const Offset &o1, const Offset &o2) const
memberdef.name: construct_segment

briefdescription.para: Same as above, with offsets.
Converts the periodic triangle of type PT to a Triangle.

detaileddescription.para: The type PT can be either Periodic_triangle or Periodic_triangle_3.

memberdef.argsstring: (const P &p1, const P &p2, const P &p3) const
memberdef.name: construct_triangle

briefdescription.para: Creates a triangle from three points.

detaileddescription.para: The type P can be either Point or Point_3.

memberdef.argsstring: (const P &p1, const P &p2, const P &p3, const Offset &o1, const Offset &o2, const Offset &o3) const
memberdef.name: construct_triangle

briefdescription.para: Same as above, with offsets.
Converts the periodic tetrahedron of type PT to a Tetrahedron.

detaileddescription.para: The type PT can be either Periodic_tetrahedron or Periodic_tetrahedron_3.

memberdef.argsstring: (const P &p1, const P &p2, const P &p3, const P &p4) const
memberdef.name: construct_tetrahedron

briefdescription.para: Creates a tetrahedron from four points.

detaileddescription.para: The type P can be either Point or Point_3.

memberdef.argsstring: (const P &p1, const P &p2, const P &p3, const P &p4, const Offset &o1, const Offset &o2, const Offset &o3, const Offset &o4) const
memberdef.name: construct_tetrahedron

briefdescription.para: Same as above, with offsets.
Tests whether p is a vertex of t by locating p in the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: If p is found, the associated vertex v is given.

simplesect.para: p lies in the original domain domain.

briefdescription.para: Tests whether v is a vertex of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j) const
memberdef.name: is_edge

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v) is an edge of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the edge is found, it gives a cell c having this edge and the indices i and j of the vertices u and v in c, in this order.
u and v are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, const Offset &offu, Vertex_handle v, const Offset &offv, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j) const
memberdef.name: is_edge

briefdescription.para: Tests whether ((u,offu),(v,offu)) is an edge of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the edge is found, it gives a cell c having this edge and the indices i and j of the vertices u and v in c, in this order.
u and v are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Vertex_handle w, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j, int &k) const
memberdef.name: is_facet

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v,w) is a facet of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the facet is found, it computes a cell c having this facet and the indices i, j and k of the vertices u, v and w in c, in this order.
u, v and w are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, const Offset &offu, Vertex_handle v, const Offset &offv, Vertex_handle w, const Offset &offw, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j, int &k) const
memberdef.name: is_facet

briefdescription.para: Tests whether ((u,offu),(v,offv),(w,offw)) is a facet of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the facet is found, it computes a cell c having this facet and the indices i, j and k of the vertices u, v and w in c, in this order.
u, v and w are vertices of t.

briefdescription.para: Tests whether c is a cell of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Vertex_handle w, Vertex_handle x, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j, int &k, int &l) const
memberdef.name: is_cell

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v,w,x) is a cell of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the cell c is found, the method computes the indices i, j, k and l of the vertices u, v, w and x in c, in this order.
u, v, w and x are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, Vertex_handle v, Vertex_handle w, Vertex_handle x, Cell_handle &c) const
memberdef.name: is_cell

briefdescription.para: Tests whether (u,v,w,x) is a cell of t and computes this cell c.

simplesect.para: u, v, w and x are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, const Offset &offu, Vertex_handle v, const Offset &offv, Vertex_handle w, const Offset &offw, Vertex_handle x, const Offset &offx, Cell_handle &c, int &i, int &j, int &k, int &l) const
memberdef.name: is_cell

briefdescription.para: Tests whether ((u,offu),(v,offv),(w,offv),(x,offx)) is a cell of t.

detaileddescription.para:
If the cell c is found, the method computes the indices i, j, k and l of the vertices u, v, w and x in c, in this order.
u, v, w and x are vertices of t.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle u, const Offset &offu, Vertex_handle v, const Offset &offv, Vertex_handle w, const Offset &offw, Vertex_handle x, const Offset &offx, Cell_handle &c) const
memberdef.name: is_cell

briefdescription.para: Tests whether ((u,offu),(v,offv),(w,offv),(x,offx)) is a cell of t and computes this cell c.

simplesect.para: u, v, w and x are vertices of t.

description.para: There is a method has_vertex in the cell class.
The analogous methods for facets are defined here.

briefdescription.para: If v is a vertex of f, then j is the index of v in the cell f.first, and the method returns true.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, Vertex_handle v, int &j) const
memberdef.name: has_vertex

briefdescription.para: Same for facet (c,i).

detaileddescription.para: Computes the index j of v in c.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, Vertex_handle v) const
memberdef.name: has_vertex

briefdescription.para: Same as the first two methods, but these two methods do not return the index of the vertex.

description.para: The following three methods test whether two facets have the same vertices.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, Cell_handle n, int j) const
memberdef.name: are_equal

memberdef.argsstring: (const Facet &f, Cell_handle n, int j) const
memberdef.name: are_equal

description.para: The class Periodic_3_triangulation_3 provides three functions to locate a given point with respect to a triangulation.
It provides also functions to test if a given point is inside a face or not. Note that the class Periodic_3_Delaunay_triangulation_3 also provides a nearest_vertex() function.

briefdescription.para: Returns the cell that contains the query in its interior.

detaileddescription.para: If query lies on a facet, an edge or on a vertex, one of the cells having query on its boundary is returned.

The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.
query lies in the original domain domain.

briefdescription.para: Returns the cell that contains the query in its interior.

detaileddescription.para: If query lies on a facet, an edge or on a vertex, one of the cells having query on its boundary is returned.
locate_offset is the offset that must be used by the function periodic_tetrahedron() together with the returned cell, so that the constructed Periodic_tetrahedron contains the query point.

The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.
query lies in the original domain domain.

briefdescription.para: Same as locate() but uses inexact predicates.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns a handle on a cell that is a good approximation of the exact location of query, while being faster. Note that it may return a handle on a cell whose interior does not contain query.
Note that this function is available only if the Cartesian coordinates of query are accessible with functions x(), y() and z().

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &query, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj, Cell_handle start=Cell_handle()) const
memberdef.name: locate

briefdescription.para: The $ k$-face that contains query in its interior is returned, by means of the cell returned together with lt, which is set to the locate type of the query (VERTEX, EDGE, FACET, CELL) and two indices li and lj that specify the $ k$-face of the cell containing query.

detaileddescription.para: If the $ k$-face is a cell, li and lj have no meaning; if it is a facet (resp. vertex), li gives the index of the facet (resp. vertex) and lj has no meaning; if it is an edge, li and lj give the indices of its vertices.
If there is no vertex in the triangulation yet, lt is set to EMPTY and locate returns the default constructed handle.

The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.
query lies in the original domain domain.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &query, Offset &locate_offset, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj, Cell_handle start=Cell_handle()) const
memberdef.name: locate

briefdescription.para: The $ k$-face that contains query in its interior is returned, by means of the cell returned together with lt, which is set to the locate type of the query (VERTEX, EDGE, FACET, CELL) and two indices li and lj that specify the $ k$-face of the cell containing query.

detaileddescription.para: If the $ k$-face is a cell, li and lj have no meaning; if it is a facet (resp. vertex), li gives the index of the facet (resp. vertex) and lj has no meaning; if it is an edge, li and lj give the indices of its vertices.
If there is no vertex in the triangulation yet, lt is set to EMPTY and locate returns the default constructed handle.
locate_offset is the offset that must be used by the function periodic_tetrahedron() together with the returned cell, so that the constructed Periodic_tetrahedron contains the query point.

The optional argument start is used as a starting place for the search.
query lies in the original domain domain.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Cell_handle c, Locate_type &lt, int &li, int &lj) const
memberdef.name: side_of_cell

briefdescription.para: Returns a value indicating on which side of the oriented boundary of c the point p lies.

detaileddescription.para: More precisely, it returns:

listitem.para: ON_BOUNDED_SIDE if p is inside the cell.
ON_BOUNDARY if p on the boundary of the cell. Then lt together with li and lj give the precise location on the boundary. (See the descriptions of the locate methods.)

ON_UNBOUNDED_SIDE if p lies outside the cell.
query lies in the original domain domain.

sectiondef.header: Cell, Face, Edge and Vertex Iterators

description.para: The following iterators allow the user to visit cells, facets, edges and vertices of the stored triangulation, i.e. in case of computing in a multiply sheeted covering space all stored periodic copies of each item are returned.
These iterators are non-mutable, bidirectional and their value types are respectively Cell, Facet, Edge and Vertex. They are all invalidated by any change in the triangulation.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary vertex.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all vertices. Returns vertices_end() if t.number_of_vertices() $ =0$.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary edge.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all edges. Returns edges_end() if t.number_of_vertices() $ =0$.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary facet.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all facets. Returns facets_end() if t.number_of_vertices() $ =0$.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary cell.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all cells. Returns cells_end() if t.number_of_vertices() $ =0$.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary vertex.

detaileddescription.para: Iterates over all vertices whose corresponding points lie in the original domain, i.e. for each set of periodic copies the Unique_vertex_iterator iterates over exactly one representative. Returns unique_vertices_end() if t.number_of_vertices() $ =0$.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

description.para: The following iterators allow the user to obtain geometric primitives corresponding to cells, facets, edges, and vertices of the triangulation.

These iterators are non-mutable, bidirectional and their value types are respectively Periodic_point, Periodic_segment, Periodic_triangle, and Periodic_tetrahedron. They are all invalidated by any change in the triangulation. If the periodic triangulation is not computed in the 1-sheeted covering space, these iterators can be used to retain only the geometric primitives in the original domain. This can be controlled using the enum Iterator_type.

center.bold: The four different modes of the geometric iterators: STORED, STORED_COVER_DOMAIN, UNIQUE, UNIQUE_COVER_DOMAIN. Note that in case of computing in the 1-sheeted covering space, STORED and UNIQUE give the same result.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the points of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_point_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the segments of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_segment_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the triangles of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_triangle_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the tetrahedra of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_3_triangulation_3::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_tetrahedron_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

description.para: The following circulators respectively visit all cells or all facets incident to a given edge.
They are non-mutable and bidirectional. They are invalidated by any modification of one of the cells traversed.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary cell incident to e.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: incident_cells

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.
Starts at cell start.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j, Cell_handle start) const
memberdef.name: incident_cells

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.
Starts at an arbitrary facet incident to e.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.
Starts at facet start.

memberdef.argsstring: (Edge e, Cell_handle start, int f) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: Starts at facet of index f in start.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j, Facet start) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c.

memberdef.argsstring: (Cell_handle c, int i, int j, Cell_handle start, int f) const
memberdef.name: incident_facets

briefdescription.para: As above for edge (i,j) of c and facet (start,f).

sectiondef.header: Traversal of the Incident Cells and Facets, and the Adjacent Vertices of a Given Vertex

briefdescription.para: Copies the Cell_handles of all cells incident to v to the output iterator cells.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
v $ \neq$ Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies the Facets incident to v to the output iterator facets.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
v $ \neq$ Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies the Edges incident to v to the output iterator edges.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
v $ \neq$ Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Copies the Vertex_handles of all vertices adjacent to v to the output iterator vertices.

detaileddescription.para:
Returns the resulting output iterator.
v $ \neq$ Vertex_handle(), t.is_vertex(v).

briefdescription.para: Returns the degree of a vertex, that is, the number of adjacent vertices.
Returns the index of c in its $ i^{th}$ neighbor.
Returns the vertex of the $ i^{th}$ neighbor of c that is opposite to c.
Returns the same facet viewed from the other adjacent cell.

description.para: The responsibility of keeping a valid triangulation belongs to the user when using advanced operations allowing a direct manipulation of cells and vertices.
We provide the user with the following methods to help debugging.

briefdescription.para: Checks the combinatorial validity of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Checks also the validity of its geometric embedding (see Section Representation). When verbose is set to true, messages describing the first invalidity encountered are printed.

briefdescription.para: Checks the combinatorial validity of the cell by calling the is_valid method of the Triangulation_data_structure cell class.

detaileddescription.para: Also checks the geometric validity of c, if c is finite. (See Section Representation.)
When verbose is set to true, messages are printed to give a precise indication of the kind of invalidity encountered.

briefdescription.para: Reads a triangulation from is and stores it in t.

detaileddescription.para:
is has the below described format. The information in the iostream is:
the original domain
the number of sheets of the covering space as in number_of_sheets()
the number of vertices
the non-combinatorial information of vertices (point resp. point-offset pairs, etc.)
the number of cells
the indices of the vertices of each cell
the indices of the neighbors of each cell, where the index corresponds to the preceding list of cells
the offsets corresponding to the vertices of the cells
the non-combinatorial information of each cell

briefdescription.para: Writes the triangulation t into os.

detaileddescription.para:
The information in the iostream is:
the original domain
the number of sheets of the covering space as in number_of_sheets()
the number of vertices
the non-combinatorial information of vertices (point resp. point-offset pairs, etc.)
the number of cells
the indices of the vertices of each cell
the indices of the neighbors of each cell, where the index corresponds to the preceding list of cells
the offsets corresponding to the vertices of the cells
the non-combinatorial information of each cell

briefdescription.para: The class Periodic_3_triangulation_3 represents a 3-dimensional triangulation of a point set in $ \mathbb T_c^3$.

parameterdescription.para: must be a model of the concept Periodic_3TriangulationTraits_3.

must be a model of the concept TriangulationDataStructure_3 with some additional functionality in cells and vertices. Its default value is Triangulation_data_structure_3<Triangulation_vertex_base_3<PT,Periodic_3_triangulation_ds_vertex_base_3<>>,Triangulation_cell_base_3<PT,Periodic_3_triangulation_ds_cell_base_3<>>>.
